foreignOwnership.q: Can foreigners own freehold property in Thailand?
foreignOwnership.a: Yes, condos allow freehold foreign ownership up to 49% of the building area. Our legal partners structure shareholding to keep you compliant.

services.q: Which services do you provide beyond brokerage?
services.a: We coordinate legal due diligence, visa strategy, rental management, school onboarding, and relocation logistics in your language.

financing.a: Select banks and private lenders extend mortgages to foreign buyers. We prepare documentation and introduce financing partners.

articles.sectionSubtitle: Brief, actionable guidance for cross-border investors and relocating families.

buyingThailand.title: How foreign buyers secure Thai property
buyingThailand.excerpt: Understand structures, fees, and timelines before you sign a booking form.

body.0: Foreign buyers typically enter the market through condominiums, which allow freehold ownership. Landed property requires company or leasehold structures. Our legal partners map the right route for your objectives.
body.1: Transfer taxes, specific business tax, and withholding tax vary between new builds and resales. We model the full cost of ownership to avoid surprise expenses.
body.2: Funds must enter Thailand in foreign currency. We coordinate remittances and provide bank templates to ensure the Land Office accepts your transaction.

visaGuide.title: Residence visa pathways for property investors
visaGuide.excerpt: Pair your purchase with the right visa to secure long-term stay benefits.

body.0: Thailand Elite, Malaysia MM2H, and Cambodia My Second Home all recognise property investment. We analyse minimum spend and processing speeds for each program.
body.1: Families often layer education, healthcare, and tax considerations into their decision. Our advisors compare benefits in plain language.
body.2: We work with certified immigration lawyers to prepare applications while your property transaction progresses.

marketPulse.title: Southeast Asia market pulse Q4
marketPulse.excerpt: Where yields are rising and how currency moves affect returns.

body.0: Rental yields in Bangkok’s riverside district climbed 7% year-on-year as new infrastructure opened.
body.1: Yangon and Phnom Penh remain value plays with dollar-linked leases shielding investors from volatility.
body.2: Ringgit weakness creates entry opportunities in Malaysia’s administrative capital. We outline hedging options.
